documentation.title: whether entitled to reward or not
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Tam lost his wireless airpods in the campus. He advertised online and near the campus, a reward of $50 to who returns the lost earphones.

Sania found them and went to return it. But next day she saw the advertisement and claim the reward. Advise Tam.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Sania is entitled to a reward of 7,50€.
---------------------------------------

[germany](/questions/tagged/germany "show questions tagged 'germany'")

In Germany, to reward honest finders, the finder of an item is entitled to 5% of a lost item's value of up to 500€ under [§ 971 BGB](https://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/bgb/__971.html). Airpods cost about 150 €, so Sania is entitled to a Fider's reward of 7,50 €. Anything more would be at the discretion of Tam, accepting less is at Sania's discretion.

Do note, that denial of the finder's reward at the moment that Sania hands over the item means, that they also deny their entitlement to the reward. In fact, it is upon Sania to demand the reward, and unless they do so, it is presumed that they do not want a finder's reward.

**However** in making her entitlement to the reward known, Sania may not cross the line into coercion or blackmail (§§ 240, 253 StGB). Should Sania say, without explanation "I demand a payment of 100 € for the airpods", that could be coercion, as she is not entitled to that. If she however says "I am entitled to finder's reward of 7,50 €, and had expenses of 2\.50 € to get the phone to you, therefore you owe me 10 €" the picture is different \- that is *exactly* the amount that the law says she would be owed. This is because atop the actual reward Sania can reclaim reasonable fees, such as the bus fare to get the phone to Tam under [§ 970 BGB](https://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/bgb/__970.html). Under § 972 BGB, Sania does not have to relinquish the item till the reward and expenses have been paid but also does not become the owner of the item.

#### The Fundbüro

To evade a possible claim for "Unterschlagung von Fundsachen" (\~conversion by not reporting a found item), the Fundbüro (Found item's office) exists when the owner can't be made out rapidly. Not only does it calculate the required finder's reward, but also handing it over to the office fulfills the requirement to report a found item that is worth more than 10 € under [§ 965 BGB](https://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/bgb/__965.html). It is customary to store the lost items at the Fundbüro, but that is not required.

To gain the item from the Fundbüro, Tam will have to pay any required handling fees to the office but also gets notice of how much he should pay to Sania as well as her contact details. Sania will get contact details of Tam in return, together with a notice that she has a claim to a reward of such value. Should Sania not have given her details, it is presumed that she did not want the finder's reward.

If Sania retained the item, the Fundbüro will inform Tam of the estimated finder's reward and contact details for Sania, so Tam can reclaim the item.

documentation.title: Copyright of retyped public domain text
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: In order to copyright something, you have to do an innovative change (photocopying doesn't count)

Does converting public domain images into text (through OCR or like wikisource) count as "innovative change" and put a copyright on the resultant text?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A thing needs to be *original* in order for it to get copyright protection.

[17 USC §102](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/17/102): "Copyright protection subsists \[...] in original works of authorship"

[Copyright Act Section 5 (1\)](http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/c-42/page-3.html#h-5): "copyright shall subsist in Canada \[...] in every original literary, dramatic, musical and artistic work..."

In the US, originality requires "a modicum of creativity" ([Feist Pubs., Inc. v. Rural Tel. Svc. Co., Inc.](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/499/340/) 
499 U.S. 340 (1991\).

In Canada, originality requires an "exercise of skill and judgment" and that "not be so trivial that it could be characterized as a purely mechanical exercise" ([CCH Canadian Ltd. v. Law Society of Upper Canada](http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/scc/doc/2004/2004scc13/2004scc13.html), \[2004] 1 SCR 339\).

Text transcribed from a public domain source would not be given copyright protection.

A) The researcher can claim copyright on the entire digital archive, including the OCR-generated text, as it required significant effort and technical skill to create.

D) The researcher cannot claim any copyright on the digital archive, as it is merely a reproduction of public domain materials.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. The researcher can claim copyright on the database structure and any original annotations, but not on the OCR-generated text of the public domain newspapers. This is because:

1. The original 19th-century newspapers are in the public domain, so their content remains free of copyright.

2. The process of scanning and using OCR to convert images to text does not meet the threshold of originality required for copyright protection. As stated in the documentation, this would be considered a "purely mechanical exercise" (Canadian standard) and lacks the "modicum of creativity" (US standard) necessary for copyright.

3. However, the overall structure of the database, including how the information is organized, indexed, and presented, may involve sufficient originality to warrant copyright protection.

4. Any original annotations, summaries, or additional content created by the researcher could also be copyrighted, as these would be new, original works.

Option A is incorrect because the effort and technical skill alone do not grant copyright without originality. Option C is wrong because OCR conversion is not considered an "innovative change" for copyright purposes. Option D is too extreme, as it ignores potential copyright in the database structure and any original contributions by the researcher.
